Acrolein (systematic name: propenal) is the simplest unsaturated aldehyde. It is a colorless liquid with a piercing, acrid smell. The smell of burnt fat (as when cooking oil is heated to its smoke point) is caused by glycerol in the burning fat breaking down into acrolein. It is produced industrially from propylene and mainly used as a biocide and a building block to other chemical compounds, such as the amino acid methionine.

The pronunciation of this chemical drives me nuts.  The brits and the yanks both say "Acro-lian", however the way it's spelled wouldn't even suggest that.  Lein--is germanic and would sound like "Line".  Ei and Ine both sound like "Line".  I stick to a German pronunciation of it because it makes sense in a written format.  No surprises really, bot American and British english have Wacky pronunciations of words that don't have english roots.

I have worked with this stuff in gallon quantities on pilot-plant scale research.  The idea that anyone would want to actually make it is mind-boggling.  The worst thing about it is the effect on the eyes.  First, your nose starts to twitch then in about 10 seconds your eyes become seriously painful. This, apparently, takes about 5-10 ppm. The only solution is to calmly walk outside into the fresh air.  Eventually you'll be able to open your eyes again.  BTW we pronounced it with the stress on the first syllable thus AK-ra-lin.

I had to use acrolein on a project making methionine.  The chemicals were not just bad they were gastly.  Acrolein was by far the best one.  Rxn 1.) Add methyl mercaptan.  Reaction 2.) Add HCN.  The HCN had to be first distilled to remove the polymerization inhibitor.  Then the uninhibited HCN made about 30% tar which had these horrendously odorous mercaptans.  I could make a 10 gram run and the people a half mile away called to head office complaining they were getting sick.

The cancer medicine Cyclophosphamide is broken down by the liver into its therapeutic molecule and acrolein. Acrolein is the toxic side product that can cause blisters in the urinary bladder as it is excreted. Those blisters can become cancerous.  Tobacco companies use to add glycerol to tobacco to keep it moist. When smoked the acrolein can damage blood vessels, including the heart.  Blaming the tars of cigarette smoke on the bladder cancer may not be entirely correct given that acrolein has also been a factor.    Cysteine and especially acetyl-cysteine will inactivate the toxicity of acrolein.  Asparagus is a good source of cysteine and maybe a useful alternative to systemic acrolein poisoning.  If you inhale it consider the respiratory form of acetyl-cysteine as a good adjunct to treat it (my opinion, as a pharmacist).

a few tips if you ever try this again. if you use a schlenk flask as the receiver to draw vacuum while its open you limit exposure dawg. lead the vacuum exhaust to a bubbler with concentrated base. add acetic acid and do NOT neutralize the acid or you shit will polymerize in a day or two as you observed. base catalyzes the polymerization. you use a low boiling chlorinated solvent to remove water then fractionally still that off. store in freezer protected from light with the HQ and acetic acid. the stuff should keep for longer than one week. we do all that when working with MVK and it keeps for 6 months but slowly inevitably polymerizes no matter what you do.

I'm glad you made this video. I have done acrolein twice. In my first synthesis I used a dropping funnel just like you and I found it completly unnecessary as well. I did't use the second flask with sodium chloride and i just took the receiving flask and used a vigreux columnfor second distillation. I also used potassium bisulfate instead of magnesium sulfate. In my first time my yield was just 17%, so next time I used twice more potassium bisulfate and that incrised my yield to 31%.  I stored my acrolein in freezer but a week latter I also had just polymers.
